The overall increase of $5.1 million is attributable primarily to: (a) increased requirements for civilian personnel owing to the application of updated vacancy rates and revised salary rates; and (b) increased requirements under facilities and infrastructure for rental of premises for the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Syria for new office space in Damascus in compliance with the Minimum Operating Security Standards. The increase was offset in part by: (a) the removal of provisions for rental of a passenger charter plane and services provided by UNOG for meetings of the international Syria Support Group and sessions of the Constitutional Committee for the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Syria; (b) reduced requirements for official travel in several missions; and (c) and reduced requirements for ground transportation for the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen owing to the discontinuation of fuel reserve in Aden and Sana’a.

The proposed vacancy rates applied in the budget take into account the experience to date. The assumptions considered for the proposed vacancy factors include the 12-month average vacancy rate in 2024 and the actual vacancy rate as at 31 March 2025. The lower of the two was used as the budgeted vacancy rate. This is in line with the policy guidance to improve the accuracy and consistency of the vacancy factors applied in the proposed budgets for 2026 and to ensure that the proposed vacancy rates are based, as much as possible, on actual rates. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied in the calculation of costs for the post proposed for reassignment or conversion.
For the sake of brevity, the present document will include a section on extrabudgetary resources only for those missions that have projected extrabudgetary resources in 2025 or 2026.
II.	Cross-cutting information
Gender perspective

Special political missions are guided by the relevant Security Council resolutions on the women and peace and security agenda, which mandate the incorporation of a gender perspective into the political work of the United Nations, including in special political missions. The missions are also guided by General Assembly resolution 75/100 on the comprehensive review of special political missions, in which the Assembly reaffirmed the important role of women in the prevention and resolution of conflicts and in peacebuilding and recognized the importance of the equal and effective participation and the full involvement of women at all levels, at all stages and in all aspects of the peaceful settlement of disputes, conflict prevention and conflict resolution.

Specific examples of how special political missions integrate a gender perspective into their operational activities, deliverables and results are given under the individual missions in the present report.
Disability inclusion

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, special political missions review the Strategy with a view to further advancing disability inclusion through inclusive messaging, awareness-raising and promoting the Strategy through their work, including in political and peace processes. The missions also support mitigating measures to overcome accessibility challenges, in addition to the efforts by relevant United Nations entities to ensure the accessibility of facilities, platforms, security and other infrastructure to facilitate easy access and use by persons with disabilities.
Evaluation activities

Note: The following abbreviations are used in the tables: ASG, Assistant Secretary-General; FS, Field Service; NGS, National General Service; NPO, National Professional Officers; USG, Under-Secretary-General.

The Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs is supporting the biennial assessment by the Office of Internal Oversight Services, initiated  in 2024 and expected to be completed in mid-2025, on strengthening the role of evaluation and the application of evaluation findings on programme design, delivery and policy directives. The results of the evaluation will guide proposed programme plans for missions grouped under thematic cluster I. In addition, the Office of Internal Oversight Services has conducted an evaluation of cluster I conflict-specific special political missions, which is currently being finalized. Mission-specific evaluation activities are described, as applicable, under the specific missions in the present report.
III.	Special political missions

text: 1.	Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on Cyprus

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mandate of the Mission derives from the priorities established in relevant Security Council resolutions and decisions and an exchange of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council (S/2008/456 and S/2008/457). In resolution 1818 (2008), the Council welcomed the intention of the Secretary-General to appoint a Special Adviser and in a letter addressed to the President of the Security Council (S/2008/456), the Secretary-General announced his intention to appoint his Special Adviser on Cyprus as from 14 July 2008. Relevant Security Council resolutions from which the mandate derives include resolution 186 (1964) and various subsequent Council resolutions, the latest being 2771 (2025).

In its resolution 2771 (2025), the Security Council fully supported the Secretary-General’s ongoing engagement and welcomed the agreed constructive next steps. The Council welcomed the Secretary-General’s plans to convene an informal broader meeting with the two sides and the guarantor powers to discuss the way forward, encouraged further informal talks, emphasized the importance of negotiating a mutually acceptable settlement under United Nations auspices and called urgently on the sides to engage with the Secretary-General and his team to this end.
Programme of work
Objective
The objective, to which this Mission contributes, is to achieve a comprehensive settlement of the Cyprus issue.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:
(a)	Support the two leaders and guarantor powers to promote a peaceful solution and to assist them, should they jointly agree, in the conduct of full-fledged negotiations;

(b)	Regularly conduct bilateral meetings and facilitate joint meetings between the leaders, and their representatives, emphasizing the importance of effective communication for conflict prevention and trust building;
(c)	Support the implementation of confidence- and trust-building measures/initiatives and the work of the technical committees.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Dialogue among the parties resulting in further rounds of informal talks towards a comprehensive and just settlement in Cyprus;
(b)	Meetings and the expansion of bicommunal contacts;
(c)	Empowerment and facilitation of the work of the technical committees, resulting in concrete measures and the implementation of confidence-building measures/initiatives.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the Mission, will coordinate the engagement of international financial institutions in support of the peace process and cooperate with the European Commission as relevant.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Mission, the United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus and the United Nations country team will maximize synergies and ensure coherent and effective support for peace efforts.
With regard to the external factors, the plan for 2026 is based on the following assumptions:
(a)  Continued and sustained political commitment of the parties to the peace process and the technical committees;
(b)	Continued and sustained international support for the peace process.

The Mission integrates a gender perspective in its activities, advocates for gender equality across the work of all technical committees, and supports women’s civil society platforms. It also advocates for greater civic inclusion and the involvement of youth and underrepresented groups.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Mission will further mainstream disability inclusion in its work, advocate for inclusion of persons with disabilities in engagement with the sides and  the technical committees, andensure accessibility and employment opportunities for qualified candidates with disabilities.
Programme performance in 2024

Engagement with the parties, decision to work on crossings, improved dialogue and chances for movement ahead, lowered tensions and raised hope among Cypriots, improving their situation vis-à-vis prospects for peace talks

On 5 January 2024, the Secretary-General appointed Ms. María Ángela Holguín Cuéllar as his Personal Envoy on Cyprus for a six-month period. Building on her work that concluded in July 2024, the Secretary-General engaged with the Cypriot leaders on 15 October, which led to an informal meeting in a broader format with the guarantor powers on 17-18 March 2025. There, the parties agreed on the appointment of a Personal Envoy, six trust-building initiatives and another broader format meeting in July 2025. Ms. Holguín was named as a Personal Envoy on 2 May 2025 to follow up on next steps.

While the number of meetings dropped in 2024, the outputs of the technical committees increased in quality, with project delivery that improved the daily lives of Cypriots. Examples include a vector-borne diseases project that mapped invasive disease-carrying species and increased public awareness on prevention; and the renovation of cultural heritage sites increasing interactions, mutual understanding, and visitors and tourists, thereby benefitting the local economy. Addressing obstacles in intra-island trade benefited businesses, while environmental concerns were addressed across the island, with projects to combat pests and clearing drinking water sources for endangered species. The decision in 2024 to continue dialogue on crossings and to meet with the Secretary-General directly benefited the parties by providing effective communication for risk-mitigation and trust building among them.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 3).
Table 3 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Engagement with the two leaders and their teams and support for senior-level engagement, including separate meetings between the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders with the Secretary-General, three visits of the Assistant Secretary-General for Europe, Central Asia and the Americas to Cyprus and one to each of the guarantor powers, and two meetings of the leaders in Cyprus

Engagement with the two leaders and their teams, including separate meetings between the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders, as well as of the guarantor powers with the Secretary-General, the Under-Secretary-General for Political and Peacebuilding Affairs and the Assistant Secretary-General for Europe, Central Asia and the Americas, respectively; and three meetings of the leaders in Cyprus

Agreement to explore the opening of new crossing points and to hold informal broader format meeting with the guarantor powers
Increased activity of civil society organizations and women’s groups 
Technical committees delivered important projects, improving the daily lives of Cypriots

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Furthering dialogue as conflict management and an inclusive and sustainable peace process towards a negotiated settlement – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Mission’s work contributed to the holding of and support to 70 bilateral and joint meetings with the leaders and their representatives and 285 meetings of the technical committees, which did not meet the planned target of 140 and 410, respectively. The target was not met primarily due to the absence of active negotiations, and the shift to planning for the high-level meetings with the two sides and guarantor powers in 2025. As a result, the planned performance target for 2026 reflects this shift.

In 2026, with the regional landscape expected to remain challenging, the Mission will focus on the support to high-level meetings, trust-building activities, the work of the technical committees and utilising dialogue as an effective early warning and conflict prevention tool.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson learned was that when meetings are convened at the highest level, focus shifts away from technical-level meetings on the island. At the same time, there is more space for progress in the higher-level dialogue, agreed initiatives and the work of the technical committees, including the new Youth Committee. The planned change would be to focus on delivery of initiatives, including by the technical committees, as they remained critical to building trust and reducing tensions across the island.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in figure I.

Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 5 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 6 – Human resources
a The Under-Secretary-General is on a when-actually-employed contract.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the Office amount to $3,198,900 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($2,919,500) for the continuation of 21 posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 D-1, 3 P-5, 5 P-4, 1 P-3, 4 Field Service, 1 General Service (Other level) and 5 Local level), as well as operational costs ($279,400), comprising costs for consulting services ($18,200), official travel ($63,000), facilities and infrastructure ($72,800), transportation ($47,400), information technology ($57,800), medical ($300) and other supplies, services and equipment ($19,900).
In 2026, no change is proposed to the number and levels of the posts.
Vacancy rates of 12.8 per cent and 16.7 per cent have been applied to the estimates for international and national staff costs, respectively, based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024.

The increase in the requirements proposed for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable to increased requirements for civilian personnel mainly due to the application of a lower vacancy rate for national staff compared with the rate of 20 per cent applied in 2025 and updated rates for salaries and common staff costs. The increase is offset in part by the reduced requirements for the non-recurring acquisition of engineering supplies, prefabricated facilities, office furniture, printers and notebook computers and the related lower freight costs.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources of $100,000 were obtained for a three-year project to conduct public opinion polling to enhance evidence based political analysis and strategic support to the Cyprus peace process.
In 2026, no extrabudgetary resources are anticipated.

text: 2.		Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on the Prevention of Genocide

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mission is mandated to collect information on massive and serious violations of human rights and international humanitarian law of ethnic and racial origin that, if not prevented or halted, may lead to genocide; to act as a mechanism of early warning to the Secretary-General and, through him, to the Security Council, by bringing to their attention situations that could potentially result in genocide; to make recommendations to the Council, through the Secretary-General, on action to prevent or halt genocide; and to liaise with the United Nations system on activities for the prevention of genocide and on work to enhance the capacity of the United Nations to analyse and manage information regarding genocide or related crimes.

The mandate derives from the invitation of the Security Council to the Secretary-General in its resolution 1366 (2001) to refer to the Council information and analysis from within the United Nations system on cases of serious violations of international law, including international humanitarian law and human rights law. The Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide was appointed through an exchange of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council (S/2004/567 and S/2004/568). The responsibilities of the Special Adviser were listed in the letter of the Secretary-General (S/2004/567). The mandate has been reaffirmed through various resolutions of the Security Council, the General Assembly and the Human Rights Council. In its resolution 77/318, the General Assembly noted the role of the Special Adviser in the launch of the United Nations Strategy and Plan of Action on Hate Speech, as part of efforts to address and counter hate speech.

With regard to the responsibility to protect, the General Assembly, in paragraphs 138 and 139 of its resolution 60/1 on the 2005 World Summit Outcome, addressed the responsibility of Member States and the international community to protect populations from genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity. The Security Council reaffirmed the provisions of paragraphs 138 and 139 of that resolution in its resolutions 1674 (2006) and 1706 (2006). Through an exchange of letters (S/2007/721 and S/2007/722), the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on the Responsibility to Protect was appointed and charged with the conceptual, institutional and operational development of the principle and with continuing a political dialogue with Member States on its implementation. The Assembly, in resolution 75/277, included an item on the responsibility to protect on its agenda and requested the Secretary-General to report annually on that item.

In its resolutions 2150 (2014) and 2171 (2014), the Security Council recalled the important role of the Special Advisers on the Prevention of Genocide and on the Responsibility to Protect, whose functions included acting as an early warning mechanism to prevent  situations that could result in genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes and ethnic cleansing.

Designated by the Secretary-General as the UN focal point for the implementation of the 2019 UN Strategy and Plan of Action on Hate Speech, the Office recognizes hate speech as a risk factor and indicator for genocide. The importance of addressing hate speech, and the Special Adviser's role, is underscored by numerous UN resolutions, including General Aseembly resolutions 75/309 (2021) and 77/318 (2023), and Security Council resolution 2686 (2023). Furthermore, General Assembly resolution 78/282 mandates the establishment of an outreach programme on the Srebrenica Genocide, beginning in 2025, starting its activities with preparations for the commemoration of the thirtieth anniversary of this genocide in 2025, and to bring to the attention of all Member States, United Nations system and civil society organizations for appropriate observance.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to advance national, regional and international efforts to protect populations from genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity and their incitement.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the mission will:

(a)	Raise awareness of the causes and dynamics of genocide through predictive and action-oriented analysis, enhanced by the collection and sharing of information from field missions and regional offices in accordance with its early warning mandate;
(b)	Alert relevant actors with respect to the risk of genocide, through the implementation of the United Nations Strategy and Plan of Action on Hate Speech, capacity-building and advocacy;
(c)	Advocate and mobilize for appropriate action to prevent the risk of genocide through engagement within the United Nations and with external partners;
(d)	Strengthen community-level efforts for prevention, including by assisting locally led initiatives aimed at bringing communities together;
(e)	Harness technology to enhance prevention and counter its negative impacts, as outlined in Human Rights Council resolution 49/9;

(f)	Increase female participation in decision-making roles and support implementation of the plan of action for women in communities to counter hate speech and prevent incitement to violence that could lead to genocide and related crimes;
(g)	Prioritize action against Holocaust and genocide denial and the glorification of war crimes and criminals;

(h)	Support the universal ratification of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide, and support efforts towards its implementation at the national level through legislation and implementation mechanisms.

The above-mentioned work is expected to result in increased capacity and action by United Nations intergovernmental bodies, Member States and regional and subregional organizations to prevent and mitigate the risk of genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity, including their incitement.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	Continued commitment of Member States, the Security Council and other intergovernmental bodies to engage with the mission to advance the prevention of genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity and enhance efforts aimed at conceptualizing the principle of the responsibility to protect;

(b)	Active engagement of Member States and regional and other organizations to develop preventive capacity and take appropriate action for the prevention of genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity, including their incitement.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission will continue to work and partner with regional organizations, including the African Union, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region, the Economic Community of West African States, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), the Organization of American States, the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) and the European Union, among others, as well as with civil society, including religious leaders, traditional leaders, academia and traditional media  on developing capacity and take appropriate action for the prevention of genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity, including their incitement, at national and regional level. In 2026, the Office will prioritize continuing and strengthening cooperation.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission works closely with and supports United Nations country teams on the implementation of the United Nations Strategy and Plan of Action on Hate Speech.

The mission integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. This includes reflecting the gender dynamics in its monitoring and analysis and striving for the equal participation of women in its capacity-building events and workshops.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the mission has developed a guidance note on integrating disability inclusion in its programmes and activities, and has launched, in November 2024, a guidance note on persons with disabilities and the prevention of genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity and on addressing hate speech to support mental health.
Programme performance in 2024
Collection of information for early warning and prevention on the risk of genocide and related crimes

In 2024, following Zambia's adoption of the Genocide Convention in 2022, and with support from the mission, the Zambian National Committee for the Prevention and Punishment of Genocide, War Crimes, Crimes against Humanity and all forms of Discrimination was launched and its members trained in Lusaka in March.

Also, four major policy documents aimed at addressing hate speech and advancing genocide prevention were adopted in 2024, providing communities with additional tools to address and respond to assessed risks. These advancements, coupled with the increased advocacy for prevention within the Mission's mandate following the adoption of General Assembly resolution 78/282 on the International Day of Reflection and commemoration of the 1995 Genocide in Srebrenica, contribute to global prevention efforts and fostering healing for affected communities.

children.text: Planned result for 2026

Enhanced protection from atrocity crimes through improved awareness and prevention mechanisms, and better risk identification capabilities for Member States and regional organizations – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Mission’s work advanced national, regional and international efforts to protect populations from genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity, and met the planned target by having 20 follow-up actions taken by Member States and regional organizations to mitigate the risk of such crimes. In 2024, the Special Adviser undertook 14 official visits, issued 28 public statements and sent eight internal notes to the Secretary-General. The mission conducted 17 workshops and eight technical assistance initiatives, supported the development of context-specific action plans on countering and addressing hate speech for six United Nations country teams and two subregions, and highlighted the voices of community-level actors through dedicated initiatives, including Sudanese women. The Mission also continued implementing its “Champions of prevention” initiative, aimed at providing visibility to community-level prevention work undertaken by civil society actors from Rwanda, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Iraq/Yazidi, Bangladesh/Rohingya and Cambodia, and advocacy campaigns were tied either to relevant international days or to Special Adviser’s missions on countering and addressing hate speech.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the mission is that collaborating with UN field entities, the International Residual Mechanism for Criminal Tribunals (IRMCT), and active NGOs and civil society organizations proved essential for expanding the Office's outreach and risk assessment capabilities. In applying the lessons, the Mission will prioritize strengthening these partnerships, particularly with NGOs and civil society organizations on the ground, to further build capacity in areas crucial for preventing genocide and related crimes.

children.text: Evaluation activities

The Office underwent an independent communication evaluation in 2024, analyzing data from 12 missions (January 2022-August 2024). The evaluation examined various communication outputs, finding that statements, speeches, and social media were the most effective advocacy tools, with potential for expansion. Based on the findings of the evaluations, the Office will improve its communication of work and achievements by embedding a strong communications culture within its operations.

For 2026, the Office plans to evaluate the impact of its 2023-2024 Plans of Action and policy documents, collaborating with the UN system, funds, programs, NGOs, civil society organizations, and Member States to determine efficient implementation methods.

The proposed resources for 2026 for the mission amount to $3,857,500 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($3,317,900) for 21 posts and positions (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 Assistant Secretary-General, 2 P-5, 4 P-4, 3 P-3, 3 P-2, 2 General Service staff (Other level)) and 5 national United Nations Volunteer positions, as well as operational costs ($539,600), comprising costs for official travel ($233,100), facilities and infrastructure ($228,200), ground transportation ($3,600), communications and information technology ($31,000) and other supplies, services and equipment ($43,700).
For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and levels of the posts.
It is proposed that two existing general temporary assistance positions be continued in 2026, as follows:

(a)	One Political Affairs Officer (P-4) to enable the office to continue its support to the implementation of the United Nations Strategy and Plan of Action on Hate Speech in a context where the global rise and spread of hate speech continue to pose a challenge worldwide. The continuation of this position would allow the Office to continue providing sustained assistance in response to requests from Member States, regional organizations and United Nations field presences for technical assistance and capacity-building in the development and implementation of context-specific action plans to address and counter hate speech.

(b)	One Associate Political Affairs Officer (P-2) to strengthen the analysis capacity of the mission and support campaigns of the Office on Holocaust denial, countering hate speech and ratification of the Convention on the Prevention and Punishment of the Crime of Genocide. The position will continue to focus on data analytics and use new technologies to research and gather information, including online trends of hate speech, as a key indicator of risk and potential trigger of genocide, war crimes, ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity, which will enable the Office to respond to these new challenges and trends in the prevention of these crimes.

Vacancy rates of 5.8 per cent has been applied to the estimates for international staff   based on the actual average vacancy rate in 2024; 25 per cent for United Nations Volunteers on the basis of the expected recruitment timeline; and zero per cent has been applied to national staff costs  based on the actual vacancy rate in March 2025.

The increase in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is mainly attributable to increased requirements for civilian personnel as a result of the application of lower vacancy rates of 5.8 per cent and zero per cent for international staff (including for 3 posts established with a vacancy rate of 50 per cent), and national staff, respectively, compared to 10.9 per cent applied in 2025, as well as the application of the continuing rate for three national United Nations Volunteers positions established with a vacancy rate of 50 per cent in 2025. The increase is offset in part by the absence of provision for consultants, the cancellation of two subscriptions for public information, and reduced requirements for conference and translation services based on utilization pattern.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources amounting to approximately $697,000 are to be utilized mainly for the staff costs of one post (P-4), the capacity-building and technical assistance programme and the preparation of the 2025 report of the Secretary-General on the responsibility to protect.

For 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the estimated amount of $492,000 would continue to provide for one post (P-4) as well as the capacity-building and technical assistance programme and the preparation of the 2026 report of the Secretary-General on the responsibility to protect.

The decrease in the estimated extrabudgetary resources to be utilized in 2026 compared with 2025 is due mainly to the completion of some projects supporting capacity-building and technical assistance work as well as decreased unearmarked contributions.

text: 3.	Personal Envoy of the Secretary-General for Western Sahara

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Personal Envoy of the Secretary-General for Western Sahara is responsible for assisting the parties, Morocco and the Frente Popular para la Liberación de Saguía el-Hamra y de Río de Oro (Frente POLISARIO), in finding a just, lasting and mutually acceptable political solution, which will provide for the self-determination of the people of Western Sahara in the context of arrangements consistent with the principles and purposes of the Charter of the United Nations.

The mandate derives from the communications between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council dated 17 March 1997 (S/1997/236), 1 October 2021 (S/2021/851) and 5 October 2021 (S/2021/852), as well as from the priorities established through Security Council resolutions. Most recently, in its resolution 2756 (2024), the Council expressed its full support for the Personal Envoy to facilitate the negotiations process in order to achieve a solution to the Western Sahara question. The Council again called upon the parties to resume negotiations under the auspices of the Secretary-General without preconditions and in good faith, and to demonstrate political will and work in an atmosphere propitious for dialogue.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to advance the parties’ efforts to achieve a just, lasting and mutually acceptable political solution, which will provide for the self-determination of the people of Western Sahara.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:

(a)	Encourage the parties to continue the discussion on the question of Western Sahara in order to identify elements of convergence, through bilateral consultations, including with the neighbouring countries of Algeria and Mauritania, conduct visits to the region to meet with key interlocutors and engage in shuttle diplomacy and other activities deemed useful in that regard;
(b)	Consult with members of the Security Council and the Group of Friends on Western Sahara, both in their capitals and in New York, as well as with regional organizations, towards a solution;
(c)	Work towards organizing two international meetings.
This is expected to result in:
(a)	Additional trust built and strengthened involvement by the parties in the political process;
(b)	Maintained support by the international community for the political process.
With regard to cooperation, the mission regularly meets with regional organizations and other relevant stakeholders to exchange views on the United Nations-led political process.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission receives support for visits and information on developments in Western Sahara from the United Nations Mission for the Referendum in Western Sahara. It also coordinates and liaises with UNHCR on visits to the refugee camps and on confidence-building measures and maintains contact with OHCHR in Geneva on issues related to the human rights situation.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	All concerned show willingness to meet for direct negotiations;
(b)	The security situation remains conducive to the mission’s objective for the region.

The mission integrates a gender perspective in its activities. It ensures that women and representatives of women’s organizations are included in meetings with civil society and will encourage delegations to include women in political meetings.
In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy the mission will include consultations with persons with disabilities and inclusion of them in meetings.
Programme performance in 2024
Readiness for engagement with all concerned

In 2024, the Personal Envoy continued his efforts to engage all concerned and undertook broadened consultations on the issue of Western Sahara with a view to constructively advancing the political process. This focused on exploring creative ideas to find a solution that would benefit the people of Western Sahara. The Personal Envoy called for flexibility and creativity in his April 2024 briefing to the Security Council, and discussed options with all concerned in the course of his bilateral engagements. The  Personal Envoy expressed his readiness to meet with all concerned. He reported on these efforts to the Security Council in October and highlighted the need for urgency.
65.	Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see figure IV).
Figure IV – Performance measure: number of rounds of engagement with all concerned
Planned result for 2026
Advancing the process on Western Sahara – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission’s work contributed to meeting the target of continued engagement between the parties and neighbours and towards advancing the political process. It was not possible to hold the two international meetings in 2024.

In 2026, the mission will continue to advance the political process through consultations with all concerned, visits to the region to meet key interlocutors, including representatives of civil society including women, and other measures. It will also continue to hold consultations with Member States in their capitals and in New York. In addition, the mission will continue to liaise with relevant United Nations entities in Geneva and other locations. The mission will also meet regularly with representatives of relevant regional organizations to exchange views on the United Nations-led process. The mission will seek to convene two international meetings.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Mission is that political will is required from all concerned to seize the window afforded by the United Nations-facilitated process. The mission will continue to engage regularly with all concerned in order to identify elements of convergence, with a view to achieving a mutually acceptable political solution.

text: 4.     Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the implementation of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004)

children.text: A. 	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

On 14 December 2004, the Secretary-General appointed his Special Envoy for the implementation of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004) to enable him to report to the Council every six months on the implementation of the resolution, as requested by the Council in its presidential statement of 19 October 2004 (S/PRST/2004/36).

In its resolution 1680 (2006), the Council reiterated its call for the full implementation of the provisions of resolution 1559 (2004), and strongly encouraged the Government of the Syrian Arab Republic to respond positively to the request made by the Government of Lebanon, in line with the agreements of the Lebanese national dialogue, to delineate their common border, especially in those areas where the border was uncertain or disputed.

In its resolution 1701 (2006), the Council emphasized the importance of the extension of the control of the Government of Lebanon over all Lebanese territory in accordance with the provisions of resolutions 1559 (2004) and 1680 (2006), and of the relevant provisions of the Taif Accords. The Council requested the Secretary-General to develop, in liaison with relevant international actors and the parties concerned, proposals to implement the relevant provisions of the Taif Accords and resolutions 1559 (2004) and 1680 (2006), including disarmament, and for delineation of the international borders of Lebanon.
In subsequent resolutions on Lebanon, the Council continued to urge all parties to make tangible progress towards all outstanding issues in the implementation of relevant Council resolutions.

In a statement by the President of the Security Council (S/PRST/2025/1) on 16 January 2025, the Council welcomed the cessation of hostilities between Israel and Lebanon of 26 November 2024 (S/2024/870). The Council called on the parties to fully implement the provisions of the cessation of hostilities understanding and for the full implementation of resolution 1701 (2006) and the Security Council’s previous relevant resolutions by all parties.

In 2016, the Under-Secretary-General for Political Affairs was tasked by the Secretary-General with assuming the responsibility of reporting on the implementation of resolution 1559 (2004), an arrangement that has been maintained to date.
Programme of work
Objective
The objective, to which this Mission contributes, is to ensure full implementation of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004) and all subsequent related resolutions of the Council.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Mission will seek to use the present momentum to foster consensus on a Lebanese-led and Lebanese-owned national dialogue, which is expected to result in progress on addressing the maintenance of weapons outside State authority;

The above-mentioned work is expected to result in informed Security Council deliberations on possible opportunities for Lebanon to make progress on the outstanding provisions of Council resolution 1559 (2004).

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission coordinates with the Office of the United Nations Special Coordinator for Lebanon, in particular in the process of developing the reports of the Secretary-General.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
The regional environment continues to affect Lebanon’s stability and security;

Following the 2025 presidential election and government formation, the ability of the Lebanese leadership to deliver reforms and tangible benefits for the population is put to the test, as they also face reconstruction challenges;

There is a greater political will by the Lebanese parties to address the disbanding and disarmament of Lebanese and non-Lebanese militias and some efforts towards that goal, though constraints persist;
International and regional Member States remain engaged in advancing the disbanding and disarmament of Lebanese and non-Lebanese militias;
Violations of Lebanese sovereignty and territorial integrity persist.

The mission integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, through ensuring appropriate consultations with all stakeholders, including women leaders, and the inclusion of gender-disaggregated data, as appropriate.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the mission will support mitigating measures to overcome accessibility challenges, in addition to the efforts undertaken by relevant United Nations entities to ensure the accessibility of facilities, platforms, security and other infrastructure to facilitate easy access and use by persons with disabilities.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced understanding of Security Council members on developments of relevance to the implementation of resolution 1559 (2004)

The Mission undertook one trip to Lebanon in March 2024, which informed the drafting of the April 2024 report of the Secretary-General on the implementation of resolution 1559 (2004). However, a trip to Lebanon planned for September 2024 did not transpire due to a vacancy in the core capacity of the mission though the mission was able to deliver on planned results.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 15).
Table 15 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Understanding of Security Council members on developments of relevance to the implementation of the outstanding provisions of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004)
Understanding of Security Council members on developments of relevance to the implementation of the outstanding provisions of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004)
Understanding of Security Council members on developments of relevance to the implementation of the outstanding provisions of Security Council resolution 1559 (2004)

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Informed Security Council deliberations through analytical reports of the Secretary-General – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The mission’s work contributed to informing Security Council deliberations on developments relevant to the implementation of the outstanding provisions of Council resolution 1559 (2004). It met the planned target of Council discussions on the two semi-annual reports to reflect the outcome of consultations on the positions of Lebanese actors vis-à-vis the maintenance of weapons outside State authority.

In 2026, the mission will continue to report to the Security Council semi-annually on progress in the implementation of the resolution, in particular the disbanding and disarmament of Lebanese and non-Lebanese militias. The changed context in Syria may offer greater opportunities for progress in the implementation of the resolution 1680 (2006).
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson is that in-person consultations are necessary to identify opportunities for progress. In applying the lesson, the mission will further leverage engagement with United Nations entities both at Headquarters and in Lebanon, in addition to maintaining its network of interlocutors in the country.

text: 5. 	Office of the United Nations Representative to the Geneva International Discussions

children.text: A. 	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mission is mandated to support the Geneva International Discussions and the Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism under United Nations auspices in Gali, Georgia, by facilitating the participation of the United Nations in the international discussions in Geneva and the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism, and by liaising and coordinating with the relevant actors. The mission is also responsible for preparing, convening and facilitating, in consultation with the other Co-Chairs, the European Union and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE), the sessions of the Geneva International Discussions as well as the periodic meetings of the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism.

The United Nations has continued to support the Geneva International Discussions on security and stability and the return of internally displaced persons and refugees, which commenced on 15 October 2008 in Geneva in accordance with the six-point agreement of 12 August 2008 and the implementing measures of 8 September 2008, mediated by the French Presidency of the European Union, following the hostilities of August 2008 (S/2009/254). In its resolution 1866 (2009), the Security Council welcomed the beginning of the discussions and requested the Secretary-General, through his Special Representative, to continue to fully support the process. The Secretary-General addressed a letter on this matter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Georgia on 29 September 2009 and the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Georgia replied to the Secretary-General on 28 October 2009.

Against the background of the “Proposals for joint incident prevention and response mechanisms”, agreed to in Geneva on 18 February 2009, the Secretary-General, on 28 September 2009, addressed a letter to the President of the Security Council in which he stated that the United Nations would continue to support the Geneva International Discussions and the Mechanism through a limited number of personnel with the task of facilitating the United Nations participation in the international discussions in Geneva and in the Mechanism, and liaising and coordinating with the relevant actors.

In a letter dated 28 December 2009 addressed to the President of the Security Council, the Secretary-General noted that the United Nations would continue to provide support for the Geneva International Discussions and the work of the Mechanism. In a letter dated 25 February 2010 addressed to the President of the Security Council (S/2010/103), the Secretary-General conveyed his intention to appoint a United Nations Representative responsible for United Nations support for the Geneva International Discussions and the Mechanism. In a letter dated 2 May 2011 (S/2011/279), the President of the Security Council informed the Secretary-General that the members of the Security Council had taken note of his intention and of the information contained in his letter of 25 February 2010. In 2018, there was an additional exchange of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council regarding the appointment of a United Nations Representative.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to advance the main agenda items of the Geneva International Discussions, including the non-use of force/international security arrangements and addressing the issue of internally displaced persons and refugees, in the context of the Discussions and the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the mission, in close partnership with the  other Co-Chairs, will continue  efforts to facilitate progress on key agenda items of  the  Discussions, and   ensure the regular meetings of the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism as result-oriented platforms for dialogue and conflict prevention.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a) 	Contributing to the objective of transitioning the Discussions from a conflict management to a conflict transformation and resolution process.
(b)	Addressing and making progress on central issues, including the non-use of force/international security arrangements and internally displaced persons and refugees.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	All stakeholders will continue to support the  Discussions  and the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism and the  engagement of the United Nations;
(b)	All  stakeholders   will  support efforts to  enhance the effectiveness of the Discussions;
(c)	The Co-Chairs will continue to collaborate closely to fulfil the mandate of the Discussions.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission coordinates with the European Union and OSCE Co-Chairs. It maintains  contact with the European Union Monitoring Mission in Georgia and OSCE, which jointly facilitate the Ergneti Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism and other relevant actors.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison,  the mission cooperates closely with entities within the United Nations system,  and other actors so as to coordinate and strengthen the role and contribution of the United Nations within the framework of the  Discussions and the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism, especially in addressing humanitarian issues.

The mission integrates a gender perspective in its activities, including engaging in advocacy for gender equality and promoting  the role of women in conflict resolution and peacebuilding, including within the framework of the Co-Chairs’ joint strategy and action plan on women and peace and security.
The mission will closely cooperate with UNOG in the implementation of the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy.
Programme performance in 2024
Continuation of efforts to achieve concrete results on key issues on the agenda of the Geneva International Discussions

Three rounds of the Discussions took place in 2024, on 4 and 5 April, 25 and 26 June and 5 and 6 November, respectively. The Co-Chairs organized three visits to Tbilisi, Moscow, Sukhumi and Tskhinvali, as well as a visit to Washington, D.C. and   New York. The Co-Chairs also briefed  the OSCE Permanent Council in Vienna on 24 October 2024. The mission undertook visits to Tbilisi, Zugdidi, Gali and Sukhumi to engage with relevant actors. Despite the mission’s efforts, no meetings of the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism took place due to persisting differences among key participants on its modalities. The Mission will continue its efforts aimed at resumption of the Mechanism.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 20).
Table 20 – Performance measure

Advancing progress on the main agenda items of  the Geneva International Discussions and – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission contributed to ensuring the engagement of all participants in the Discussions and help prevent the resumption of hostilities. The target of progress  on the  agenda of the  Discussions could not be achieved, owing primarily to persistent differences in positions among the participants.

In 2026, the mission, in cooperation with the other Co-Chairs, will continue efforts to advance progress on substantive agenda items and ensure the regular functioning of the Gali Incident Prevention and Response Mechanism on the basis of the established principles and practices.
Lessons learned and planned change in 2026

The lesson for the mission was the  importance of continuous engagement with all stakeholders, including utilizing virtual and other means, as appropriate. In applying the lesson, such efforts will continue.

text: 6.	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Syria

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mission is responsible for promoting a solution to the conflict in the Syrian Arab Republic and facilitating an inclusive, comprehensive and credible Syrian-owned and -led political solution that will meet the legitimate aspirations of the Syrian people for dignity, freedom and justice based on the principles of equality and non-discrimination. The mandate derives from the priorities established by the Security Council in resolutions 2118 (2013), 2254 (2015), 2268 (2016) and 2336 (2016), as well as by the General Assembly in resolution 66/253 A, which appointed a special envoy.

The ousting of the former president and his government in December 2024 has brought new opportunities and challenges and the Security Council has underlined (S/PRST/2025/4) the need for a lasting political solution in line with the principles of Security Council resolution 2254 (2015). It is critical to focus on an orderly, credible and inclusive Syrian-owned and -led political transition fully supported by the United Nations and based on a solid legal framework, leading towards a new constitution and free and fair elections in line with the principles of Security Council resolution 2254 (2015).
Programme of work
Objective

The objective of this mission is to advance the full implementation of all the relevant General Assembly and Security Council resolutions towards an inclusive, credible, comprehensive Syrian-owned and -led political solution to the conflict in the Syrian Arab Republic that meets the legitimate aspirations of the Syrian people for dignity, freedom and justice, based on the principles of equality and non-discrimination and with the full and meaningful participation of women.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:

(a)	Engage with the Syrian authorities, all Syrian parties and the broadest possible spectrum of Syrian society as well as all key regional and international stakeholders on a Syrian-led and owned inclusive and credible political transition;

(b) 	Support the Syrian authorities and all Syrian parties to put in place stable, credible, and inclusive transitional arrangements for the mid-term that inspire public trust and confidence and that provides a path to long-term, inclusive governance, based on a new constitution and free and fair elections, that unfold in a safe, calm and neutral environment, and which is inclusive of all Syrians and in accordance with international standards, in line with the principles of Security Council resolution 2254 (2015);

(c) 	Coordinate international action and support to achieve those goals, through the Special Envoy’s good offices to advise, support and convene international and Syrian stakeholders – as and when deemed helpful;
(d) 	Advocate for de-escalation and prevention of violence in Syria. Work towards a nationwide ceasefire;

(e)	Advocate for the respect, protection and fulfilment of human rights of all Syrians. Promote accountability for serious violations and the preservation of documentation and evidence to safeguard the right of the victims and their families and survivors to both truth and justice;

(f)	Engage the Humanitarian Task Force of the International Syria Support Group to address urgent needs and advocate for international support, including steps toward lifting sanctions in line with economic recovery;

(g)	Promote women’s meaningful participation in the political transition by engaging relevant actors and forums, including Syrian-Syrian dialogues, the Women’s Advisory Board, and the Civil Society Support Room. Advocate for the direct inclusion of women leaders, experts, and organizations in all transition processes.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Sustained, regular and substantive dialogue among relevant stakeholders on all issues outlined in Security Council resolution 2254 (2015);
(b)	A political transition that reflects Syrian women’s meaningful participation and rights, by integrating their perspectives into decision-making and governance structures;
(c)	Increased trust in the political transition among Syrians and key regional and international stakeholders, supported by strong international consensus and a transitional justice framework;

(d)	The release of essential financial and technical assistance from the international community, coordinated by the UN, for reconstruction, gradual economic recovery across all regions of Syria, and the reintegration into the global economy.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Most national, regional and international stakeholders will cooperate with the Special Envoy;
(b)	Syria’s governance will remain challenging but with moves towards a more inclusive, balanced and stable framework of power sharing;

(c)	The security situation will likely remain volatile in 2026, with internal conflicts and external interventions posing serious challenges and with the potential to negatively affect civilians, especially women and children, risking more civilian casualties, renewed displacement and further destruction of civilian infrastructure as well as human rights violations.
(d)	Legitimate processes for accountability and transitional justice are coupled with genuine efforts for social peace and reconciliation among Syrians.

(e)	The Syrian economy will remain fragile, requiring sustained international financial and technical support throughout 2026 and beyond, along with significant adjustments to address imposed sanctions.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission partners with the international community and international NGOs to facilitate and support its work, including the Syrian Civil Society Support Room and the Syrian Women’s Advisory Board. On detention and missing persons, it coordinates with specialized Syrian and international bodies, including the ICRC and the Independent Institution on Missing Persons.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission cooperates with UN Country Team and the Inter-Agency Task Force on Syria which ensures the coordination and coherence of United Nations political, humanitarian, human rights and other efforts in the country.

The Mission integrates gender, disability, and anti-racism perspectives across its operations. This includes renewing its 2025–26 Gender Strategy to address the political transition, promoting the UN Disability Inclusion Strategy through staff training and communication, and advancing the Strategic Action Plan on Racism in coordination with the UN Anti-Racism Office.
Programme performance in 2024
Opportunites emerge to  support a credible and inclusive Syrian-owned and -led political  transition based on the principles of Security Council resolution 2254 (2015) –

Throughout the year, until the ouster of the former president and his government in early December 2024, the Special Envoy continued to carry out the Secretary-General’s good offices, prioritizing engagement with the Government of the Syrian Arab Republic and the opposition Syrian Negotiation Commission. The Special Envoy also continued to consult broadly with regional and international stakeholders to seek to maximize coherence and coordination among diplomatic efforts and to foster a constructive multilateral approach in line with resolution .

Following the ouster of the former president and government, efforts focused on stabilizing the situation, protecting civilians, and preserving Syrian institutions, while supporting a Syrian-owned and -led political transition toward an inclusive, credible, non-sectarian government in line with resolution 2254 (2015). Extensive consultations were held with Syrian and international stakeholders, including the de facto leadership in Damascus, to encourage concrete international steps. These efforts helped create space for dialogue with Damascus and caretaker authorities.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 25).
Table 25 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Constitutional Committee discussed draft constitutional texts. The Office shared ideas with the Committee’s Co-Chairs on ways to expedite the work and produce results and continued progress. No consensus was found on a venue for resuming the Constitutional Committee or on ways to address substantive challenges facing the Committee. Proposals by the Special Envoy to advance step-for-step confidence-building measures in line with Security Council resolution 2254 (2015) were tabled

No progress was made in advancing mediation between the former government and opposition. After 8 December, national, regional and international stakeholders were brought in and benefited from systematic consultations with the mission with a view to supporting an orderly, credible and inclusive transitional process

children.text: Planned result for 2026

Promoting a comprehensive, inclusive, sustainable political solution in line with Security Council resolution 2254 (2015), through a coherence multilateral approach, a new constitution, and free and fair elections, with broad Syrian support as well as in line with international principles and standards. –  – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, efforts to advance the Constitutional Committee and step-for-step confidence-building measures stalled. While these tracks did not yield the intended progress, detailed discussions were held with Syrian and international actors on a new, comprehensive approach to implement Security Council resolution 2254 (2015). Following the ouster of the former president, focus shifted to supporting an orderly, credible, and inclusive Syrian-owned transition. Looking ahead to 2026, the mission will prioritize advancing a renewed political transition roadmap grounded in resolution 2254 (2015).

In 2026, the mission intends to gradually shift its focus from immediately advocating for and supporting an orderly, credible, and inclusive Syrian-owned and -led political transition to promoting long-term transformative political arrangements, based on a new constitution and free and fair elections, inclusive of all Syrians and in accordance with international standards, in line with the principles of Security Council resolution 2254.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the mission was the need to promote with key stakeholders a new, comprehensive approach that would address the full range of issues. Events have obviously superseded the notion of talks between the former Syrian government and the Negotiation Commission. The mission will therefore need to continuously work in a nimble fashion, adapt and increase the pace of response and proactive advice to the Syrian authorities as changes unfold. Key priority for the mission in this new phase is to engage with the broadest possible spectrum of Syrian society and Syrian parties as well as regional and international stakeholders in order to help ensure that the Syrian-owned and -led political transition will be orderly, credible, inclusive, and based on the principles of Security Council resolution 2254 (2015).

For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and levels of the posts.

Vacancy rates of 27.5 per cent and 15.4 per cent have been applied to the estimates for international staff and General Service and Local level staff, respectively, based on the actual vacancy rates in March 2025. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the estimates for National Professional Officers based on the actual average vacancy rate in 2024.

The increase in the requirements proposed for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to: (a) increased requirements for civilian personnel, resulting from the application of lower vacancy rate of 27.5 per cent compared with the rate of 32.7 per cent applied in 2025 for international staff, and the application of the latest salary rates; as well as (b) higher requirements for facilities and infrastructure owing to the need for additional office space in compliance with Minimum Operating Security Standards in Damascus. The increase  is offset in part by the reduced requirements for air operations due to the removal of provisions for rental cost of a passenger charter plane and for services provided by UNOG for meetings of the international Syria Support Group and sessions of the Constitutional Committee.

text: 7.	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Horn of Africa

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mandate of the mission derives from an exchange of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council (S/2018/955 and S/2018/979), when the remit of the mandate of the former Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Sudan and South Sudan was expanded to cover the entire Horn of Africa region, following previous exchanges of letters (including S/2016/258 and S/2016/259). In line with the letters of 2018, the mission also continues to carry out the functions previously performed by the Special Envoy for the Sudan and South Sudan relating to the maintenance of good and peaceful neighbourly relations between the Sudan and South Sudan, established pursuant to the exchange of letters between the Secretary-General and the President of the Security Council in 2011 (S/2011/474 and S/2011/475). The mandate includes cooperation with the African Union High-level Implementation Panel in efforts to implement Security Council resolution 2046 (2012), in which the Council called upon the Sudan and South Sudan to reach an agreement on critical issues, including: (a) the full and urgent advancement of all outstanding issues from the Comprehensive Peace Agreement; and (b) the easing of tensions and the facilitation of the resumption of negotiations on post-secession relations and the normalization of their relations. Furthermore, the mission works closely with and supports member states of the Intergovernmental Authority on Development (IGAD), in line with the Joint Framework for Cooperation between the United Nations and IGAD signed in Djibouti on 17 November 2015, and other regional organizations in promoting peace and security across the Horn of Africa.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective to which this mission contributes is to establish and maintain good and peaceful neighbourly relations between the countries of the Horn of Africa region, encompassing Djibouti, Eritrea, Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, South Sudan, the Sudan and Uganda, to consolidate and sustain gains in peace and security and enhancing regional conflict prevention.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:

(a)	Promote regional peace and security, socioeconomic development and integration, inclusive and responsive governance, and awareness of linkages between climate and peace and security. This will be done in line with the Pact of the Future and by providing political leadership for the UN engagement in these areas and ensuring joined-up action through the regional prevention and integration strategy for the Horn of Africa.

(b) 	Support IGAD in strengthening the link between early warning and early response, increasing its capacity to respond to and resolve conflicts, and improving information-sharing and knowledge management. This will be done by deploying the Secretary-General’s good offices and leveraging the collective influence of IGAD member States to support dialogue and joint initiatives among the countries;

(c) 	Work closely with and support the African Union and other relevant regional organizations in addressing recent and emerging security threats in the Horn of Africa. This will be done through information-sharing, regular meetings with relevant partners and other special envoys in the Horn of Africa and the development of appropriate messages and approaches for supporting regional peace and security.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Subregional capacities are strengthened and  relations and mutual trust and confidence between countries of the region to address the root causes of conflicts are improved;
(b)	Synergies between partners in the region and the alignment of interventions and responses with the respective strategic frameworks of the UN, IGAD and the African Union are strengthened;
(c)	The implementation plan of the regional prevention and integration strategy is reviewed and operationalized.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	IGAD and the African Union continue to be fully engaged in the maintenance of peace and security in the region, paying particular attention to Ethiopia, Somalia, Sudan and South Sudan;

(b) 	States in the region continue to engage constructively with the Special Envoy and continue to work with the United Nations in the area of capacity-building, in particular in the area of mediation and conflict prevention and resolution;

(c) 	South Sudanese parties, with support from the region, progressively show commitment to the implementation of the Revitalized Agreement on the Resolution of the Conflict in the Republic of South Sudan and are prepared to consolidate gains;

(d)	The relationship between the Sudan and South Sudan remains constructive despite the war in the Sudan, enabling direct negotiations between the two countries on outstanding bilateral issues, including the situation of Abyei and its final status.
(e) 	The relationship between Somalia and Ethiopia continues on a path of de-escalation.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission works closely with IGAD and its member States, as well as other organizations such as the African Union and the European Union, to address the regional dimensions of crises and conflicts in the Horn of Africa, focusing on their cross-border and regional implications, and supporting political cooperation and regional integration. The mission cooperates with the African Union to support the bilateral negotiations between the Sudan and South Sudan to resolve outstanding issues, including finding a settlement to the issue of the final status of Abyei. The mission works with other United Nations entities to provide technical and advisory support to the IGAD secretariat.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison the mission engages with special representatives of the Secretary-General, resident coordinators and peace and development advisers in the countries of the region, and with UN agencies, funds and programmes that are active in the areas identified as collective priorities by the UN system to ensure a more coherent approach to prevention strategies and approaches.

The Mission integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, in its good offices and planned missions, including seminars and workshops, by including gender-sensitive and focused activities. The mission works with relevant stakeholders to promote inclusive messaging to enhance the participation of women in all political and peace processes, and actively engages in regional and global meetings to lobby for accelerating the implementation of the women and peace and security agenda.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the Office will provide support to IGAD and the African Union, as relevant, to enhance the inclusion of persons with disabilities in political, peace and security initiatives.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced collective action in implementing the prevention agenda in the Horn of Africa and deepened partnership in the region through collaboration with the Intergovernmental Authority on Development

In 2024, to enhance regional prevention and following a review of the comprehensive regional prevention strategy, the mission launched a new prevention and integration strategy informed by the priorities of IGAD and reflecting current challenges. The mission continued to coordinate the implementation of the strategy, including the publication of three joint regional analysis reports, the operationalization of a climate, peace and security hub, and the launch of a policy on countering hate speech. The Special Envoy carried out good offices, including continuing to focus on the peace process in Ethiopia, Ethiopia’s relationship with its neighbours, engaging with stakeholders on the crisis in Sudan, and engaging with relevant officials on relations between the Sudan and South Sudan.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 30).
Table 30 – Performance measure

table_content.text: IGAD-UN partnership strengthened and IGAD capacity to address issues related to climate, peace and security and women and peace and security enhanced through the development of the regional action plan for women, peace and security and a regional climate security coordination mechanism
Revision of regional prevention and integration strategy completed and endorsed, leading to more focused priorities for engagement of the UN system in the Horn of Africa.

Launch and implementation of the new regional prevention and integration strategy, contributing to increased collaboration amongst UN entities and its partners in the region and more impactful engagement of the UN system to address conflict and its root causes in the region.

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Enhanced collective action in implementing the prevention agenda in the Horn of Africa – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission’s work contributed to deepened collaboration in addressing peace and security issues between IGAD, the African Union and the UN, for example on issues related to interstate tensions such as between Ethiopia and its neighbours, and thematic issues such as the role of women and youth in peace and security, as well as the impact of climate change on peace and security. Work also included implementing the new regional prevention and integration strategy, which met the planned target.

In 2026, the mission will continue to carry out good offices, including supporting ongoing peace processes and political transitions within the region by working with the African Union, IGAD, respective member states and regional actors. This will result in improved regional approaches to preventing crises and conflict. The mission will continue to coordinate the implementation of the revised regional prevention and integration strategy.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the mission was the need to continually review and adjust the implementation plan of the regional prevention and integration strategy, bearing in mind available resources and capacities.In applying the lesson, the mission will continue to engage stakeholders to ensure that identified priorities are still relevant in the current context to engage with actors in the region, including other Special Envoys, to identify entry points for intervention.
