text: 8.	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Great Lakes Region

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mandate of the Mission derives from Security Council resolution 2098 (2013) and various subsequent Council resolutions, the latest being resolution 2773 (2025). Established in 2013, the Mission is responsible for supporting the implementation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework for the Democratic Republic of the Congo and the Region, which was signed on 24 February 2013 by Angola, Burundi, the Central African Republic, the Congo, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Rwanda, South Africa, South Sudan, Uganda, the United Republic of Tanzania and Zambia, as well as representatives of the United Nations, the African Union, the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR) and the Southern African Development Community, acting as guarantor institutions. On 31 January 2014, Kenya and the Sudan also signed the Framework. The Framework outlines national, regional and international commitments required to end the recurring cycles of violence in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo and address the root causes of conflict in the region.

In relevant resolutions the Council emphasized the importance of commitments undertaken by the region under the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework and reiterated its support for the regional efforts underway with regard to the East African Community-led Nairobi process and the African Union-mandated Luanda process. In resolutions 2765 (2024) and 2773 (2025), the Council called on the Special Envoy to intensify his engagement to support the full implementation of the Framework as well as to support regional peace processes and strengthen regional diplomatic mediation efforts.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this Mission contributes, is to advance the effective implementation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework by supporting and facilitating political, security and economic engagements between the signatory countries, while ensuring coherent and coordinated support from regional and international organizations and other partners, in line with the United Nations Strategy for Peace Consolidation, Conflict Prevention and Conflict Resolution in the Great Lakes Region and its action plan.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:
Support signatory countries in efforts to implement the revitalized Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework;
Provide the Secretary-General’s good offices and enhance support to regional peace processes, including through assistance to mediation efforts and the implementation of respective agreements;
Support the implementation of regional non-military approaches against armed groups; and help strengthen existing security cooperation mechanisms;
Support the effective participation of civil society, women and youth in political and peacebuilding processes; promote the economic empowerment of youth;
Promote regional economic integration, including the implementation of the recommendations of the high-level regional workshop on natural resources held in 2021 in Khartoum;
Promote regional judicial cooperation and monitoring of human rights, including by supporting the implementation of the 2019 Nairobi and the 2022 Kinshasa Declarations.

Support the implementation of the United Nations regional strategy and its 2025-2027 Plan of Action, through effective coordination and provision of secretariat support to the Senior Policy Group and Implementation Support Mechanism.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
Signatory countries of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework implement recommendations from the revitalization process towards addressing conflict root causes;

Signatory countries engage faithfully in regional peace processes and implement political agreements reached contributing to de-escalation of bilateral tensions and improving the security and humanitarian situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo;

Concerned countries enhance cooperation to address the threat posed by armed groups and coordinate regional disarmament, repatriation, and reintegration initiatives through the Contact and Coordination Group on non-military measures and its Operational Cell;
An increased number of civil society organizations, including women and youth contribute to regional peace processes and cross border peacebuilding initiatives;

Signatory countries strengthen regional judicial cooperation through the Great Lakes Judicial Cooperation Network, leading to an increased number of joint investigations, legal assistance and extradition requests, as well as prosecutions of cross-border crime;
Signatory countries increase economic cooperation and implement initiatives to curb the illicit exploitation of and trade in natural resources, with a focus on artisanal gold and coltan;
United Nations entities enhance coordination and ensure greater alignment between national strategic cooperation frameworks and the regional strategy’s objectives.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

Despite some progress as a result of diplomatic efforts, relations between some countries in the region will remain tense. The situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo will continue to face persisting insecurity and proliferation of armed groups;

Regional and international diplomatic efforts will lead to the signing in 2025 of an agreement to end the current crisis in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo, which will require implementation support;
Regional political processes will continue, requiring sustained support from the United Nations, regional and international partners to ensure the full implementation of agreements reached;
Continued support will be required for the participation and contribution of women and youth in peace processes and community peacebuilding;
Signatory countries of the revitalized Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework will demonstrate renewed political will to implement commitments made under the Framework;
International Partners will continue to support efforts towards a political settlement of the conflict in the Great Lakes region.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the Mission will enhance coordination with the ICGLR to support complementary approaches under the revitalized Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework and the Pact on Security, Stability and Development in the Great Lakes Region. To further align approaches with international partners, the Special Envoy will continue to participate in the International Contact Group.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Mission will continue to closely work with MONUSCO. Support to regional peace efforts will be coordinated through a dedicated mechanism, involving MONUSCO, UNOCA, and UNOAU. The Senior Policy Group, chaired by the Special Envoy, along with its Implementation Support Mechanism and the Integrated Secretariat, will continue to ensure alignment among United Nations entities in the region, leveraging expertise and information sharing across offices, thereby enhancing resource efficiencies, while maintaining the distinct mandates of each entity.

The Mission integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. In addition to high-level advocacy initiatives, the Mission supports the Advisory Board for Women, Peace and Security (WPS) in the Great Lakes Region in its efforts to promote women’s participation in peacebuilding, political and electoral processes and to strengthen the monitoring and evaluation capacities of the mechanisms on sexual and gender-based violence of the International Conference on the Great Lakes Region (ICGLR).
Programme performance in 2024
Advancement of the women and peace and security (WPS) agenda for the effective revitalization of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework

In 2024, the mission advanced the WPS agenda and advocated for women’s inclusion in regional political processes. The mission, together with ICGLR and partners, launched the regional Gender Barometer, a tool to enhance data and analysis on WPS and advance gender equality across ICGLR Member States. The first Gender Barometer report was validated in October 2024 and endorsed by the Ministers in charge of Gender in ICGLR Member States in November.

To amplify the voices of women in regional peace efforts, the mission organized a regional women’s forum in cooperation with the Government of Burundi, as chair of the Regional Oversight Mechanism. The forum recommended the appointment of a goodwill ambassador to champion the aspirations of women in the region. An additional regional forum was organized in Luanda under the leadership of President João Lourenço. The forum proposed the mobilization of existing mechanisms comprising women leaders to support the mediation efforts under the Luanda Process and the establishment of a trust fund for women working on peace and security. The mission also enhanced partnerships with the AU and ICGLR to promote women’s inclusion in dialogue and peace processes.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 35).
Table 35 – Performance measure

table_content.text: High-level advocacy by the Special Envoy on the need for a stronger participation of women in peace and political processes

The Special Envoy and the AU facilitated a women-led mission to the DRC to promote women's participation in regional political processes and assess the deteriorating security and humanitarian conditions in IDP camps
Increased awareness of WPS progress and challenges in the region through the development of the regional Gender Barometer and validation of its first report

children.text: Planned result for 2026
A revitalized Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework better addresses the root causes of recurrent crises in the Great Lakes region – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission provided technical support to the development of a draft action plan for the revitalisation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework, aiming at ensuring enhanced implementation of the commitments made by the signatory countries. The Special Envoy undertook good offices efforts to address the ongoing security and humanitarian crisis in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo and to promote a de-escalation of bilateral tensions. The mission provided technical support to the Nairobi and Luanda processes and promoted a convergence of views among the signatory countries on issues driving conflict dynamics. The mission also supported efforts to identify foreign ex-combatants willing to repatriate and facilitated the adoption of a draft common criminal policy on cross-border crime.

However,  due to the deteriorating security and humanitarian situation in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo and increased tensions between the Democratic Republic of the Congo and Rwanda, some engagements were postponed, notably a project on economic cooperation, land and conflict, missions of the Contact and Coordination Group as well as a meeting of the Advisory Board for WPS.

In 2026, the mission will continue to support the implementation of the recommendations developed for the revitalisation of the Framework to ensure enhanced coordination and complementarity among regional peace initiatives as well as a more concerted international support thereto. This includes the disarmament, repatriation and reintegration of foreign armed combatants operating in eastern DRC, the transparent management of natural resources and renewed cooperation on criminal conflict-related cross-border cases, among others. The office will integrate WPS and gender perspectives to enhance capacities and opportunities for women to participate in conflict prevention and regional peace processes, and promote social cohesion in the Great Lakes.
Lessons learned and planned change

The escalating crisis in the region has highlighted the need for closely aligned efforts at regional and international levels to support dialogue and confidence-building as well as the continued political will of the concerned  parties to commit to a political settlement of the conflict; and enhanced support to efforts to address the root causes of recurrent conflict in the region. In response, the Special Envoy will further step up the Secretary-General’s good offices efforts, supported by enhanced technical support from the Mission to the ongoing regional peace processes, including to the implementation of agreements reached. As part of the revitalization of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework, the Mission’s support will focus on priority areas of addressing conflict root causes.
Expected progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 36).
Table 36 – Performance measure:

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the mission amount to $5,623,800 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($4,884,200) for the continuation of 30 posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 D-2, 1 D-1, 5 P-5, 7 P-4, 5 P-3, 1 Field Service, 1 National Professional Officer, 1 General Service (Other level)) and 7 Local level, as well as operational costs ($739,600), comprising costs for consultants and consulting services ($22,000), official travel ($296,000), facilities and infrastructure ($23,500), ground transportation ($19,600), air operations ($15,600), communications and information technology ($122,300), medical ($12,900) and other supplies, services and equipment ($227,700).
For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and levels of the posts.

Vacancy rates of 12.7 per cent and 12.5 per cent have been applied to the estimates for international and General Service and Local level staff, respectively, based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied to the estimates for the National Professional Officer on the basis of the expected recruitment timeline for the post.

The increased in the requirements proposed for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to increased requirements for civilian personnel, resulting from the application of a lower vacancy rate of 12.7 per cent compared with the rate of 19.3 per cent applied in 2025 for international staff, and the application of the latest salary rates. The increase is offset in part by: (a) the non-recurring acquisition of furniture and IT equipment; (b) reduced requirements for air operations in line with historical  flight hour utilization rates; (c) reduced requirements for individual contractors; and (d) lower requirements for other services with respect to financial administrative services under other supplies, services and equipment class.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $1,800,000 are estimated to support the implementation of the Peace, Security and Cooperation Framework through various projects under different thematic areas.
In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $1,500,000 are estimated to support the implementation of the project for the reduction of small arms circulation in the Great Lakes region.
The decrease in the estimated extrabudgetary resources to be utilized in 2026 as compared with 2025 is due to lower projected contributions pending renewed agreements with partners.

text: 9.	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mission is responsible for carrying out the good offices of the Secretary-General to enable the resumption of a peaceful, inclusive, orderly and Yemeni-led political transition process that meets the legitimate demands and aspirations of the Yemeni people, including women and youth, for peaceful change and meaningful reform, as set out in the Initiative of the Gulf Cooperation Council and its implementation mechanism and the outcomes of the comprehensive National Dialogue Conference. The mandate derives from Security Council resolution 2014 (2011) and from subsequent Council resolutions, the latest being resolution 2742 (2024).

To ensure the implementation of Security Council resolutions 2014 (2011) and 2051 (2012), together with the political transition agreed in November 2011 under the Initiative of the Gulf Cooperation Council and its implementation mechanism for the political transition process in Yemen, the Secretary-General established the Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on Yemen, in accordance with an exchange of letters with the President of the Security Council in June 2012, which was then subsumed into the Office of the Special Envoy (S/2012/469 and S/2012/470).

In line with Council resolution 2216 (2015), as well as other Council resolutions on Yemen, including resolutions 2014 (2011), 2051 (2012), 2140 (2014), 2201 (2015), 2451 (2018), 2452 (2019), 2722 (2024), 2742 (2024) and the letter from the Secretary-General addressed to the President of the Security Council (S/2016/488), the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen will continue to mediate between the parties to end the conflict. The mission will provide facilitation and technical advice on the negotiation and design of interim political, economic and security arrangements, including towards the resumption of an inclusive, intra-Yemeni political process, under United Nations auspices, and enable the resumption of a peaceful, inclusive, orderly and Yemeni-led political transition process.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to achieve a negotiated political settlement between the parties to end the conflict in Yemen and enable the resumption of a peaceful, inclusive, orderly and Yemeni-led political transition that will lead Yemenis towards a path of sustainable peace.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:
(a)	Utilize negotiations, consultations and shuttle diplomacy to achieve an agreement between the parties to end the conflict in Yemen and resume the political transition;

(b)	Support the Yemen peace process in political and  technical  areas, including in helping the parties identify long-term measures and immediate priorities for political, security and economic issues to resume the political process, implement the Stockholm Agreement and de-escalate the conflict  locally, nationally and regionally;

(c)	Develop a consultative process involving women, civil society and youth, that assesses and integrates their views and recommendations in the mission’s multitrack diplomacy and negotiations on the peace agreement and post-transition process;
(d)	Foster continued regional and international support for resolving the conflict in Yemen;
(e)	Continue to adapt to the evolving political context and operational environment to strengthen mandate implementation.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

(a)	A peace agreement, or set of agreements, between the parties on political, economic and military/security measures that will improve the living conditions in Yemen and usher in a sustainable, peaceful and inclusive transitional period;

(b)	Enhanced engagement with diverse Yemeni political and social stakeholders, including women, youth, media entities and the broader public to inform the  United Nations-facilitated political process and strengthen two-way communication;
(c)	Refined security governance options and effective implementation of transitional security arrangements;

(d)	Development of an inclusive transitional agenda informed by women’s and gender perspectives, ensuring these perspectives inform relevant substantive agreements, arrangements, and implementation mechanisms and bodies;
(e)	Continued implementation of the Stockholm Agreement, including the uninterrupted flow of commercial imports into the Hudaydah ports, and further  exchanges of conflict-related detainees.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission also engages closely with international and regional organizations, including the League of Arab States, the Gulf Cooperation Council, the European Union, the International Committee of the Red Cross, and other international partners including international financial institutions.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission cooperates with the Resident/Humanitarian Coordinator and the United Nations country team in Yemen. The mission consults and coordinates closely with the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs and special political missions in the region. In line with Security Council resolution 2452 (2019), the mission closely coordinates with the United Nations Mission to Support the Hudaydah Agreement (UNMHA), which reports to the Secretary-General through the Special Envoy and the Under-Secretary-General for Political and Peacebuilding Affairs, and shares an integrated support structure with UNMHA.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	Despite a complex mediation environment due to regional dynamics, sanction regimes and limitations on staff movement in Houthi-controlled areas, the parties to the conflict will continue to engage in discussions with the Special Envoy, with the aim of reaching a comprehensive political settlement;

(b)	The mission will maintain its presence in Yemen and continue to have access to key Yemeni stakeholders including through digital means, albeit with restrictions imposed by the parties and the security situation on the ground;

The mission integrates a gender perspective in its operations and engages with national and local initiatives that promote women’s political participation and representation, citizenship rights and the incorporation of women’s human rights and security needs in transition, early recovery, conflict resolution and peacebuilding processes.

In line with the UN Disability Inclusion Strategy, the mission will enhance physical access to its office in Yemen, following similar upgrades in Amman in 2024. The mission will also continue its staff awareness-building activities on  disability inclusion.
Programme performance in 2024
Longest period of low level of hostilities since start of conflict continues without a formal truce

The period of relative stability along the Yemeni frontlines continued throughout 2024 due to the United Nations mediated truce, on which Yemenis continue to place much significance. The mission focused on establishing a road map to operationalize and implement commitments agreed upon in December 2023, which included a set of measures to improve the lives of Yemenis, while dialogue and planning continued on de-escalation and a nation-wide ceasefire. Meetings were held with political, economic, and military representatives, as well as media, civil society, women and youth, across multiple governorates in Yemen and in the region to gather their feedback on political, economic and security issues. These activities occurred amidst growing regional and economic tensions, affecting essential financial services. On 23 July 2024, the mission announced that the parties agreed to measures to de-escalate tensions in the banking and air transport sectors. Additional complexities arose from the Houthis’ arbitrary detention of various UN, diplomatic and civil society personnel, leading to a severe restriction on civic space. The mission is working with all stakeholders to secure their immediate and unconditional release.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 40).
Table 40 – Performance measure

table_content.text: The United Nations-mediated truce lasted from 2 April to 2 October 2022, and represented the longest period of calm in the eight-year conflict. The truce contributed to a significant reduction of violence and civilian casualties. It started providing relief to Yemenis as a result of regular commercial flights between Amman and Sana’a and an increase in fuel imports through Hudaydah port

Despite the formal expiry of the 2022 truce, hostilities remained limited. Throughout 2023, flights between Sana’a and Amman continued, and the continued opening of Sana’a airport facilitated the mobility of Yemenis, including for humanitarian and medical reasons. Fuel shipments and deliveries of non-food/non-medicine cargo and construction materials into the ports of Hudaydah also continued after the expiry of the truce

The main provisions of the 2022 truce largely held, despite occasional flare-ups. Hostilities across Yemeni frontlines remained limited and contained. Flights between Sana’a and Amman resumed quickly after a brief halt, with the continued opening of Sana’a airport significantly enhancing the mobility of Yemenis for humanitarian and medical purposes. Fuel shipments and deliveries of essential non-food and construction materials to Hudaydah ports persisted.

children.text: Planned results for 2026 – Result 1: international community mobilized in support of implementing a Yemeni-led, inclusive peace process –  – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the mission updated the international community on its efforts and interactions with Yemeni interlocutors. Consultations fostered exchanges on supporting a Yemeni-led political process. Intensified track 2 dialogues broadened outreach among Yemeni civil society.

In 2026, the mission will enhance collaboration with the international community to bolster engagement with the parties. Additionally, the mission will continue to engage with international NGOs to support peacebuilding activities.

Increased focus on diverse Yemeni perspectives throughout Yemen and the diaspora through intensified engagement with the international community.

Continued engagement of the international community to ensure consistent support and accompaniment of the Yemeni peace process. Regular consultations with a diverse range of Yemeni stakeholders to ensure the inclusion of their priorities in the peace process
Creation of strategic and inclusive initiatives and fostering of partnerships to transform international support into actionable and sustainable solutions for a Yemeni-led peace process.

children.text: Result 2: expanded political engagement and consultations to better include diverse Yemeni perspectives and enhanced impetus towards a Yemeni-owned and sustainable peace
Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The mission in 2024 exceeded its target of 27 formal consultations with Yemeni interlocutors, with actual 54 consultations conducted. Efforts will focus on broadening inclusion through the mission’s presence in Yemen and Jordan, as well as engaging with engaging  with Yemeni stakeholders both locally and regionally, including through field visits.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson learned is the importance of interdisciplinary approaches to achieve a more inclusive peace process and enhance mediation efforts. In applying the lesson, engagements will address cross-cutting issues and emphasize Yemeni voices including through digital means.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the mission amount to $16,657,800 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for salaries and common staff costs ($11,393,900) for 101 continuing posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 D-2, 1 D-1, 6 P-5, 15 P-4, 10 P-3, 23 Field Service, 13 National Professional Officer, and 1 General Service ( Other level) and 30 Local level posts), including the proposed staff changes below, as well as operational costs ($5,263,900), comprising costs for official travel ($360,200), facilities and infrastructure ($2,946,800), ground transportation ($229,600), air operations ($393,800), communications and information technology ($831,900), medical ($203,300) and other supplies, services and equipment ($298,300).
In 2026, the following changes are proposed for staffing:

Reassignment of a post of Medical Officer (National Professional Officer) in Aden as Associate Engineer in the Engineering and Facilities Management Unit, given the growing operational requirements to manage engineering and facilities management activities in Aden including those currently outsourced to contractors in support of the Chief Engineering Unit based in Hudaydah. The position is needed to maintain facilities,  and ensure uninterrupted power and water supply, manage waste and resolve issues raised by staff;
Conversion of a Procurement Assistant (Field Service) post to a Procurement Assistant (Local level) post in Amman, to improve the structure of the unit and to nationalise and build capacity;

Redeployment of an Information System Assistant (Field Service) post from Amman to Sana’a to ensure uninterrupted information and communication technology (ICT) support in Sana’a as a critical business continuity measure, particularly in situations of unexpected movement restrictions.

Redeployment of a Telecommunication Technician (Field Service) post from Sana’a to Aden to align it with the increased number of staff presence in Aden and ensure required telecommunications technical expertise;

Reassignment of a Security Officer (Field Service) based in Sana’a as Administrative Assistant within the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary General for Yemen in Amman, to meet the growing workload in the Office.

Vacancy rates of 21.1 per cent and 27.9 per cent have been applied to the estimates for international staff and General Service categories, respectively, based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024, and 30.8 per cent has been applied to the estimates for National Professional Officer posts based on actual vacancy rate in March 2025.

The increase in requirements proposed for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025, is attributable to higher requirements for civilian personnel, resulting from the application of latest salary rates, higher common staff costs, and the application of lower vacancy rates of 21.1 per cent and 30.8 per cent, respectively, for international staff and National Professional Officers, compared with the rates of 23.6 per cent and 42.9 per cent, respectively, applied in 2025. The increased requirements are offset in part by the reduced requirements, for : (a) facilities and infrastructure due to application of lower cost-share percentages for the Office of the Special Envoy from 67% to 58% for Sana’a and Aden’s office, parking lot lease and security services; (b) for  ground transportation owing to  the discontinuation of fuel reserve in Aden and Sana’a, and (c) for air operations due to realigning aviation fuel and rental costs of the fixed-wing aircraft in line with the historical flight hour utilization rates.
Extrabudgetary resources
In 2025, an estimated amount of $4 million extrabudgetary resources  will support the Special Envoy’s efforts to reach sustainable, and inclusive agreements to end the conflict in Yemen.
In 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the estimated amount of $4 million are projected to support the same activities as in 2025.

text: 10.	Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General on Myanmar

children.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mission is responsible for the provision of the Secretary-General’s good offices through discussions involving all relevant stakeholders and assistance to Myanmar. The mandate was defined by the General Assembly resolution 72/248 and since renewed on a yearly basis, most recently in resolution 79/182. In its first resolution on Myanmar, resolution 2669 (2022), the Security Council reinforced the urgent need to end the human suffering, and provided further guidance on the scope of work of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General, including by  encouraging close coordination  with the Special Envoy on Myanmar of the ASEAN Chair. The situation in Myanmar continues to deteriorate following the military takeover of February 2021, with serious implications for the human rights of the Rohingya Muslims and other. Fighting between the Myanmar armed forces and ethnic armed organisations and other resistance forces has continued to intensify and severely affected civilians.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which the mission contributes, is to support a Myanmar-led democratic and peaceful nation-building process and the creation of conducive conditions for the voluntary, safe, dignified and sustainable return and reintegration of Rohingya in Myanmar.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective and address the deteriorating situation in Myanmar, the mission will:

(a)	Implement a multitrack approach, in accordance with the Pact for the Future action 16 (g), including strengthening cooperation between the United Nations and ASEAN. In close coordination with the Special Envoy of the ASEAN Chair and United Nations partners, the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General will seek to support Myanmar-led processes for the resolution of the crisis The Special Envoy will complement regional efforts to support effective implementation of the ASEAN Five-Point Consensus aligned with the needs of the people of Myanmar, and support the UN system’s coordinated humanitarian and development engagement;

(b)	Advocate for a Myanmar-led process towards a peaceful, democratic and inclusive future in line with the Pact for the Future actions. In support of this, the Special Envoy will help promote a coherent international and regional approach. The mission will continue to initiate inclusive and participatory approaches with minorities, youth and women, whose voices are critical to fostering social cohesion and developing a way out of the current political crisis in line with the will of the people;

(c)	Continue efforts to create a conducive environment for the voluntary, safe, dignified and sustainable return to Rakhine State of the forcibly displaced Rohingya in the region, including from Bangladesh. The Special Envoy will continue to promote a political solution that addresses the underlying issues in consultation with the Rohingya, and to advocate for the improvement of the conditions of Rohingya on the ground, in line with the recommendations of the Advisory Commission on Rakhine State and, as appropriate, any decision from the planned 2025 High-level Conference on the situation of Rohingya Muslims and other minorities in Myanmar.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:
(a)	Improved conditions for the safe, voluntary, dignified and sustainable return of forcibly displaced populations;
(b)	Creation of conducive conditions for a de-escalation of violence and an increase in trust among communities;
(c)	Greater international and regional political support towards Myanmar-led processes for the resolution of the crisis;

(d)	Key stakeholders advance discussions toward the establishment of a Myanmar-led process on restoring democratic and human rights norms and there is continued engagement with all stakeholders to identify potential for common ground.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

(a)	The impact on civilians across Myanmar from the continued violence since the military takeover, serious human rights violations and the need for civilian protection will remain a significant challenge in restoring peace in the country;

(b)	The situation will continue to require concrete actions to contribute toward improved conditions to allow for the safe, dignified, voluntary and sustainable return of the Rohingya and reintegration in Myanmar. The rights and security of the Rohingya people need to be guaranteed and embedded in Myanmar-led solutions towards a peaceful, democratic and inclusive future;

(c)	Illicit activities and related financial flows, closely linked to the conflict in Myanmar and the downfall of the formal economy, will continue to hamper conflict resolution and impede socioeconomic and development efforts.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, the mission works in partnership with ASEAN, especially the Special Envoy of the ASEAN Chair, other key regional organizations, such as the Organization of Islamic Cooperation (OIC) and the European Union (EU), neighbouring countries and international donors to mobilize support to Myanmar-led processes for the resolution of the crisis.

With regard to inter-agency coordination, the mission coordinates closely with the United Nations system through established channels, in close consultation with the Resident Coordinators in Myanmar and Bangladesh. The Special Envoy of the Secretary-General continues to carry out the good offices mandate in close cooperation with the United Nations country team, regional offices and Headquarters, as well as human rights mechanisms on Myanmar mandated by the Human Rights Council. The mission also works in partnership with relevant UN entities to foster inclusion of diverse and vulnerable groups, such as women and youth, in dialogue processes.

The mission integrates gender perspectives in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate, and supports efforts to strengthen the capacity of Myanmar women to participate regionally and globally in women, peace and security engagements and to amplify the voices of the most marginalized women.
In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the mission will foster the inclusion of people with disabilities into its political strategy and its efforts on building inclusion.
Programme performance in 2024
Strengthened, international and regional partnerships, including on creating conditions for the safe, dignified and voluntary repatriation of displaced persons –

Since onboarding in May 2024, the Special Envoy focused on strengthening relations with ASEAN, meeting with the ASEAN Secretary General, the Special Envoy of the ASEAN Chair on Myanmar and Heads of State/Government and Foreign Ministers, including during her regional tour to ASEAN Member States and to other neighbouring nations such as China. The Special Envoy outlined to the General Assembly Third Committee that she puts an emphasis on urging neighbouring countries to leverage their influence on stakeholders in Myanmar to end the conflict.

In 2024, the Special Envoy established contact with all key stakeholders, including local communities in Rakhine State, displaced populations and their host countries in the region. The Special Envoy regularly engaged with conflict parties, civil society, community leaders, women’s groups, human rights activists and other key stakeholders from Myanmar, including Rakhine with a view to de-escalating the violence and promoting inclusive Myanmar-led processes. The Special Envoy actively advocated for protection and assistance to refugees and displaced persons.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 45).
Table 45 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Repatriation was further delayed by the escalating violence throughout Myanmar, including in Rakhine State

Repatriation was further delayed due to the devastation caused by Cyclone Mocha in May 2023 and the escalating violence throughout Myanmar, including in Rakhine State, where fighting between the Arakan Army and the Myanmar armed forces resumed in November 2023

Repatriation was further delayed due to the escalating violence throughout Myanmar, including in Rakhine State, where fighting between the Arakan Army and the Myanmar armed forces intensified throughout 2024 leading to further displacement and civilian casualties

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Progress towards improved humanitarian conditions and a Myanmar-led inclusive, democratic and peaceful nation-building process – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the work aimed to contribute towards sustainable solutions for the Rohingya, which did not meet the planned target of facilitating local initiatives in support of social cohesion. The target was not met due to the deterioration of security conditions in Myanmar, including in Rakhine State, where fighting between the Arakan Army and Myanmar armed forces continued. The mission continues to engage key stakeholders to advocate for improved conditions in Rakhine that would allow for the safe, dignified and sustainable return of refugees. In 2026, the mission, in cooperation with ASEAN, will concentrate efforts on supporting Myanmar-led processes to resolve the crisis in line with the elements set out in the ASEAN Five-Point Consensus.
Lessons learned and planned change

A lesson learned for the mission was the importance of partnerships and coordination with key regional organizations as stipulated in the Pact for the Future, namely ASEAN and OIC, and also International financial institutions and across the UN System. To this end, the Special Envoy will continue to strengthen cooperation with ASEAN and the Special Envoy of the ASEAN Chair to garner regional support for concrete initiatives that support Myanmar-led solutions towards a peaceful, democratic and inclusive future for the country.
Expected progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 46).
Table 46 – Performance measure

table_content.text: The Special Envoy elevated international engagement on the Rohingya through a visit to Bangladesh and by reinforcing cooperation with OIC
The Special Envoy deepened coordination with ASEAN and OIC, including on addressing the situation of the Rohingya, and engaged neighbouring States during visits to India and China

The Special Envoy engaged key actors advocating for the cessation of violence and improved humanitarian access and conditions, including in Rakhine State, and implemented a women, peace and security initiative

The Special Envoy engages key actors advocating for a cessation of violence and resolution of the crisis in Myanmar, including in Rakhine State, to support conditions for sustainable and inclusive peace, conducive to the return of refugees

In coordination with ASEAN, the Special Envoy supports a Myanmar-led process to find a political solution, advocate for the rights of the Rohingya as part of an inclusive future and address systemic inequalities affecting marginalized groups.

After a security assessment conducted by the Department of Safety and Security of the Secretariat in early 2022, all international staff were temporarily relocated from Nay Pyi Taw to Bangkok and are hosted in the compound of the Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific.
For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and levels of the posts.

It is proposed to continue the general temporary assistance (GTA) position of an Administrative Assistant (Local level) in Bangkok. The continuation of the GTA position in Bangkok would provide necessary administrative support to the Mission’s international staff who are temporarily relocated to Bangkok.

A vacancy rate of 25 per cent has been applied to the estimates for international posts based on the actual average vacancy rates in 2024. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied to the estimates for the Local level (general temporary assistance) position based on the expected recruitment timeline for the position.
The increase in the requirements proposed for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to the application of revised salary rates.
Extrabudgetary resources

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources of $547,600 will be used to support activities and relevant initiatives aimed at promoting the implementation of General Assembly resolution 79/182 and would provide for one P-5 and one P-3 post for part of the year, and one P-2 post for the full year..
In 2026, extrabudgetary resources of estimated $180,000 are projected to support the continuation of activities.
The decrease in extrabudgetary resources in 2026 is due to donor agreements that are due for renewal in the fourth quarter of 2025 in line with the mission’s single-year donor agreements practice.

In 2025, extrabudgetary resources in the amount of $1,644,400 are currently projected, which will include provision for five positions (1 D-1, 1 P-5, 1 P-4, 1 P-3 and 1 FS) supporting overall management in the office of the Personal Envoy in Addis Ababa, critical expertise on developing political and mediation strategies for the Personal Envoy, developing communication strategies and media encounters for the Personal Envoy, developing strategies for women participation in the various activities undertaken by the office of the Personal Envoy. The resources will also cover expenses related to the mediation efforts of the Personal Envoy and operational costs.

For 2026, extrabudgetary resources in the estimated amount of $898,300 would continue to provide for three positions (1 D-1, 1 P-3 and 1 Field Service), in the light of the unpredictability of voluntary contributions. The mission will aim to maintain personnel capacity and operational costs at levels comparable to the previous year.

A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026
Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The mandate of the Office of the Personal Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Sudan derives from Security Council resolution 2715 (2023), in which the Council, expressing alarm at the continued violence and humanitarian situation, in particular violations of international humanitarian law and grave human rights violations and abuses, welcomed the appointment of the Personal Envoy to use his good offices with the parties and the neighbouring States, complementing regional peace efforts, including those of the African Union and the Intergovernmental Authority on Development, and called on all parties to extend their cooperation in furtherance of his tasks. This was reiterated by the Council in its resolution 2724 (2024), in which it encouraged the Personal Envoy to use his good offices with the parties and the neighbouring States, complementing and coordinating regional peace efforts. In its resolution 2736 (2024), the Council called on the parties to the conflict to seek an immediate cessation of hostilities, leading to a sustainable resolution to the conflict, through dialogue, with the continued support of the Personal Envoy and the African Union High-Level Panel on Sudan. The Council encouraged the coordinated engagement of the Personal Envoy with the African Union, the League of Arab States and other key regional actors, to help advance peace and an inclusive and comprehensive Sudanese-led political process, with the full, equal, meaningful and safe participation of women, that reflected the aspirations of the Sudanese people.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to seek an immediate cessation of hostilities, leading to a sustainable resolution to the Sudan conflict, and to advance a lasting peace through dialogue and an inclusive and comprehensive Sudanese-led political process that reflects the aspirations of the Sudanese people.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the mission will:

Through good offices, consultations and shuttle diplomacy, support dialogue between the parties towards a cessation of hostilities, enhanced protection of civilians, and the launch of an inclusive Sudanese-led political process, with the full, equal, meaningful and safe participation of women, in close collaboration with national, regional and international stakeholders;

Support the coordination of international mediation initiatives by bringing together key regional and international stakeholders to enhance the overall effectiveness, coherence and integration of these initiatives and maximize their comparative advantages;

Foster continued regional and international support for resolving the conflict in the Sudan, notably through advocacy, frequent dialogue and information exchange. Efforts will be aimed at harmonizing tracks of multilateral engagement, maximizing impact and leveraging peacemaking efforts, and advancing strategies on ensuring an inclusive process;

Sustain and support consultations with a broad range of Sudanese civilian forces, including women and youth, to contribute to the United Nations initiatives aimed at advancing a cessation of hostilities, improving civilian protection in the Sudan and supporting an inclusive Sudanese-led political process.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

Parties make progress towards a negotiated cessation of hostilities, including through localized or issue-specific agreements, including those relating to transitional security arrangements, the protection of civilians, and the advancement of humanitarian access;

Peace efforts are better coordinated, with enhanced clarity on the roles and respective responsibilities of stakeholders, on the basis of comparative advantage and taking account of capacities, leverage and any prior engagement on the issues, while giving effect to the principle of partnership and ensuring effective coordination of facilitation and other engagements;

Mediation or facilitation frameworks are established and possible outcomes of the peace and political processes agreed. Specifically, options for formal and informal mechanisms for collaboration and coordination are to be considered as accompanying architecture for aligning initiatives and strategy, harnessing leverage, mobilizing support and implementing agreements, including short-term arrangements;
Civilian stakeholders are effectively engaged and informed on United Nations peacebuilding and peacemaking initiatives.

With regard to cooperation, and coordination with other entities, the mission will liaise closely with all international and regional stakeholders involved in support of peace efforts in the Sudan, in particular the African Union, the Intergovernmental Authority on Development and the League of Arab States, as well as neighbouring States. In doing so, it will work through established regional and Member State mechanisms to deepen strategic and operational engagements in carrying out good offices and mediation. It will also liaise closely with civilian actors through the various established civilian peacemaking platforms.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the mission will work closely with the Resident Coordinator/Humanitarian Coordinator and the agencies, funds and programmes of the United Nations operating in the Sudan and the region and will coordinate closely with the Department of Political and Peacebuilding Affairs and special political missions and peacekeeping operations in the region, as appropriate.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

The situation in the Sudan is likely to remain volatile with a possibility of further fragmentation of political and military dynamics. While a nationwide agreement on a cessation of hostilities may take time, there could be temporary, localized ceasefires;

The international community will remain actively engaged in support of peace efforts in the Sudan and the parties to the conflict will continue to engage in discussions with the Personal Envoy to advance a Sudanese led political process.

The mission integrates a gender perspective in its operational activities, deliverables and results, as appropriate. The mission supports activities to advance gender-related issues and provides support for greater civic engagement towards more inclusive peace and political processes.

In line with the United Nations Disability Inclusion Strategy, the mission will seek to promote disability inclusion internally by creating space for employment opportunities for qualified candidates. At the political level, it will advocate for inclusion of the views of persons with disabilities in decision-making platforms, as change agents for peace, security and sustainable development.
Programme performance in 2024
Increased sensitization of warring parties to protection of civilians issues

The personal Envoy initiated dialogue with the parties on critical issues aimed at alleviating the impact of the war on the civilian population, notably strengthening the protection of civilians and improving humanitarian access. Further to the adoption of Security Council resolution 2736 (2024), the Personal Envoy convened an initial round of proximity talks in Switzerland in July focused on these issues, which were attended by representatives of both parties, establishing a format for future discussions. The talks provided an opportunity for engagement on concrete measures to improve the lives of civilians in the Sudan. These discussions also contributed to the development of options contained in the report of the Secretary-General on “Recommendations for the protection of civilians in the Sudan” (S/2024/759). To strengthen the mission’s outreach to and partnership with Sudanese civil society, in December the mission undertook a series of virtual consultations with representatives of Sudanese youth movements, women’s groups and other civil society actors on the protection of civilians to inform future discussions with the warring parties and ensure their outcome benefits local populations in the Sudan.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 50).
Table 50 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Commitment by both warring parties to enhance the protection of civilians, including the implementation of the Jeddah Declaration

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Increased coherence of mediation initiatives in support of peace and of the launch of an inclusive political process
Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Personal Envoy set up mechanisms to enhance the coordination of mediation initiatives on the Sudan. It encouraged information-sharing among partners and built support for collective efforts in favour of peace in the Sudan through the establishment of the Sudan Consultative Group, which brought together leading multilateral organizations and Member States involved in mediation efforts on three occasions. In addition to providing support to the meetings of the Group, the Personal Envoy convened a Mediators Planning Retreat in the Republic of Djibouti on 25 and 26 July to further strengthen the coherence of international peace efforts.

In 2026, the mission will continue to engage with national, regional and international stakeholders to enhance the coherence and integration of mediation initiatives in support of the peace process and the launch of a political process, ensuring close linkages between peace and political efforts. The mission will engage with the parties to build confidence in mediation efforts and encourage them to engage in the peace process. The mission will also support inclusive and cohesive efforts to bring civilian stakeholders together to engage in a credible political process charting a way towards a negotiated political settlement.
Expected progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 51).
Table 51 – Performance measure

text: Annex I Summary of follow-up action taken to implement decisions and requests of the General Assembly, including the requests and recommendations of the Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions endorsed by the Assembly

table_content.text: Action taken to implement the recommendation

Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions
A/79/7/Add.2 and A/79/7/Add.19

Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions
A/79/7/Add.2 and A/79/7/Add.19
The Advisory Committee trusts that updated information on the regional work of the Office will be provided in the next budget submission (para. 10.a)

The Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on the Prevention of Genocide maintains active collaboration with various regional organizations. In 2024, it concluded several Memoranda of Understanding, including in Africa with the East African Community (EAC) and with a number of prevention partners. Additionally, the deployment of new Political Affairs Officers (UNVs) across regional UN presences has significantly enhanced the Mission's participation in regional activities and improved communication channels with these organizations.

The Advisory Committee trusts that the vacant posts, including the long-vacant ones and the local posts, will be filled as soon as possible and that an update on the recruitment status will be provided to the General Assembly at the time of its consideration of the present report and in the next budget submission. The Committee also trusts that the Secretary-General will propose appropriate budgetary actions in the next budget submission for any long-vacant posts that have not been recruited. (para. 11)

Information on the status of recruitment of long-vacant posts is presented in annex I of the supplementary information for each thematic cluster.
The missions under Cluster I make strong efforts to recruit and fill vacant posts in accordance with staff selection policy. Recruitment exercises, however, may be affected and inadvertently delayed due to external factors including visa restrictions; availability of qualified candidates in the duty stations; and temporary restrictions on hiring in efforts to mitigate financial challenges facing the organization (i.e. liquidity pressure) which adversely impacts the missions’ ability to fill vacant posts. Despite these challenges, missions will continue to make every effort to fill all current and future vacancies as expeditiously as possible.

The Advisory Committee trusts that more information on the complementarity and coordination among entities working on tackling hate speech across the United Nations, along with related resource implications, will be provided in the context of future budget proposals. (para. 20)

The Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on the Prevention of Genocide is the UN system-wide focal point on Hate Speech, coordinating the implementation of the UN Strategy and Plan of Action on Hate Speech within the UN System. In this capacity, the Office coordinates and chairs the UN Working Group on Hate Speech that comprises of 19 UN entities that work on tackling hate speech from the perspective of their specific mandates. The UN Strategy and Working Group enables the UN system to bring together its efforts under a common vision and strategic objectives, as outlined in the Strategy, and to ensure maximum impact across the UN system.

The Advisory Committee trusts that information on support services provided by other entities to the special political missions under cluster I, along with related amounts and any efficiency gains, will be provided in the context of the next budget report. (para. 21)

Building on best practices and maximal efficiency gains, UNFICYP provides administrative and logistical support (as part of its delegation of authority) to the Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on Cyprus at no charge in the areas of finance/budget, human resources management, and logistics including communications and IT, and, also at no charge, support by the UNFICYP spokesperson and gender adviser and the security sections of both offices work in an integrated manner. 
Support services for the Office of the United Nations Representative to the Geneva International Discussions are provided by UNOG.
The Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen continues to receive administrative support from Kuwait Joint Support Office.
ESCAP continues to be the primary service provider for the Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General on Myanmar. With ESCAP being the main service provider, the mission benefits from the economy of scale from ESCAP’s operation who provides services for entities and agencies in Asia Pacific region.

The Advisory Committee again trusts that special political missions under cluster I will take into consideration lessons learned and best practices from proven fundraising strategies, with a view to strengthening their efforts to obtain sufficient, predictable and sustained levels of voluntary contributions, including unearmarked funding, as necessary. The Committee trusts that an update will be provided in the next budget submission (see also A/78/7/Add.2, para. 25). (para.22)

The missions under Cluster I engage in different fundraising efforts to encourage donors to finance flagship initiatives to accelerate the implementation of their respective mandates. Despite these efforts, achieving significant success in this regard remains a challenge.
For example, the Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on Cyprus successfully engaged in fundraising and obtained $100,000 from an external donor for a period of three years (2025-2027) to conduct island-wide opinion polls, enhancing its ability to deliver fact-based in-depth political analysis, with a special focus on the women, peace and security aspect of the Cyprus issue.
The Office of the Special Adviser on the Prevention of Genocide has over the last several years issued regular global appeals for voluntary contributions outlining its priorities and needs. The last global appeal was published in January 2024. The Office will continue this practice and continue its regular engagement with member states on priorities and needs related to voluntary contributions. However, given the current global financial climate, the Office is encountering challenges in mobilizing additional resources to fully support its core activities.
The Office of the Special Envoy for the Great Lakes region diligently engages with its primary donors to secure voluntary contributions in support of the implementation of the Peace, Security, and Cooperation Framework. In addition to its ongoing efforts to enhance fundraising strategies, the Office will engage with other similar special political missions and other United Nations entities to exchange lessons learned and best practices. This collaboration will help strengthen the Office’s approach to obtaining sufficient, predictable, and sustained levels of voluntary contributions, including unearmarked funding, as necessary. By leveraging insights from proven fundraising strategies, the office aims to improve its approach and increase the level of voluntary contributions from the current levels.
The Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen has aligned its resource mobilization efforts. In addition, the Office has put in place improved internal reporting on resources management that takes into consideration all funding extrabudgetary portals.

The Advisory Committee again trusts that efforts will be intensified to achieve a more equitable geographical representation of Member States among the staff of the special political missions under thematic cluster I and that an update will be provided in future programme budget submissions (see also A/78/7/Add.2, para. 26). (para. 23)

Special political missions have taken measures to strengthen efforts to achieve equitable geographical representation in their workforce. In many missions, hiring managers are required to demonstrate, using the current data on geographical representation, the impact of such recommendations. The revised template of the selection memorandums now allows hiring managers to review, before a candidate is selected, whether the proposed selection improves the geographical representation of the mission. The data are also monitored on a quarterly basis through the management dashboard to guide the course of recruitment actions. 
The geographical representation, by country, of the international staff posts in all special political missions is provided centrally in annex XVIII of document A/80/6 (Sect. 3)/Add.1.

The Advisory Committee again trusts that efforts will be intensified to achieve gender balance among the staff of the special political missions under thematic cluster I and that an update will be provided in future programme budget submissions (see also A/78/7/Add.2, para. 26). (para. 24)

Special political missions have taken measures to strengthen efforts to achieve gender balance in their workforce. In many missions, hiring managers are required to demonstrate the impact of their hiring recommendation, using the current data on gender representation. The revised template of the selection memorandum allows hiring managers to review, before a candidate is selected, whether the proposed selection improves the gender representation of the mission. The data are also monitored on a quarterly basis through the management dashboard to guide the course of recruitment actions. 
For example, the Office of the Special Adviser to the Secretary-General on Cyprus is dedicated to promoting diversity and achieving gender parity within its international workforce
The Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Horn of Africa takes into consideration gender balance in all its recruitment processes. The Mission will endeavour to continue advancing gender balance and will provide updates in future programme budget submissions.
The Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Great Lakes Region is fully committed to advancing gender parity, prioritizes fostering an enabling environment that attracts women, promotes work/life balance policies, and ensures gender parity is a key consideration in recruitment and talent management. 
The Office of the Special Envoy of the Secretary-General for Yemen strives to achieve gender balance with its international recruitments and all Hiring Managers are required to take this into consideration before making recommendations for selection.

The Advisory Committee trusts that updated information on the provision of operational and administrative support by the United Nations Office to the African Union to the Office of the Personal Envoy will be included in the next report of the Secretary-General  (A/79/7/Add.19 para. 17)

As of 1 January 2025, all administrative and operational support for the Office of the Personal Envoy of the Secretary-General for the Sudan is being provided by United Nations Office to the African Union (UNOAU), including human resources, financial and logistical support. UNOAU continues to provide local administrative and logistical support services to the staff of the Office of the Personal Envoy, including office space, computer equipment, connectivity and associated technical support, local transportation support, security services, medical access to the United Nations Health Care Centre of the Economic Commission for Africa, host country support services and the requisitioning of low-value procurement goods and services. A memorandum between the United Nations Office to the African Union and the Office of the Personal Envoy is under consideration.
